captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

So again I find myself drawn back to a game I 
played on my Wednesday stream and again it&#39;s a

soulslike in which you play a cute animal. Guess 
we&#39;ve found the winning formula. Maybe I could

finish Elden Ring at last if I were to mod the 
main character into Hello Kitty. Our subject is

Nine Sols - sols without the U, mind, no copycats 
here - which comes to us from Red Candle Games,

who you might recall got into the shit - 
or perhaps I should say the Pooh - with

the Chinese government over their last 
game, and perhaps as a result decided to

play a bit safer with their new one. &quot;We&#39;re 
making a 2D cartoon platformer about a cute

little jumpy cat dude hanging out with all 
their animal pals of varying species.&quot; Well,

as long as you avoid depicting anyone as a yellow 
bear in a red shirt that&#39;s probably for the best,

Red Candle Games. Tell me more about your cute 
animal game. &quot;Well, the protagonist has to murder

all their adorable animal friends because they 
form the governing committee of a techno-fascist

failed utopia-&quot; Okay, tell me less about your 
cute animal game. I was taking the piss, but I

think Nine Sols took that advice anyway, &#39;cos 
on the outset the story doesn&#39;t tell you shit.

All you know is that the main character, 
Yi - named after the sound my wife makes

when I pinch her bum - gets thrown off a 
cliff and is nursed back to health amid a

village of friendly primitive humans who seem 
to live entirely peaceful and contented lives.

So I of course was waiting for the inevitable 
next bit where the fucking Mongols or whatever

sweep through and set fire to the place, 
and to my surprise, that didn&#39;t happen,

really. Instead we discover we&#39;re on a gigantic 
space station where the humans are being farmed

for their meat or something and Yi is a 
sort of stoic badass super warrior cat

who at one point may have been part of the 
station&#39;s government but who now has to go

around assassinating the rest of the party 
members so he can take over the station,

possibly as a means to save the primitive humans 
or possibly for mysterious reasons of his own.

Yi&#39;s an intriguingly complex character whom we 
learn about piece by piece through the course of

the game. At first he seems like a relatively 
stock anime emotionally subdued badass type

with a secret heart of gold and commitment 
to justice that makes him want to protect

the humans, but every now and again he does 
something incredibly ruthless and horrible.

Feels like we&#39;re playing as Ori from Ori and 
the Blind Forest after he grew out of his

hippie naturist phase and went to business 
school. Ah yes, Ori and the Blind Forest,

that&#39;s a good game to bring up, it being one 
of many 2D action Metroidvanias Nine Sols

takes influence from. Hollow Knight, there&#39;s an 
even better one. In fact, if you want the quick

asshole smug dismissive comparison-based summary, 
Hollow Knight was to Dark Souls what Nine Sols is

to Sekiro. By which I mean, it&#39;s a cartoon 2D 
version of an aggressively parry-focused combat

system. Parrying&#39;s the only game in town. It&#39;s 
Parry Goldwater. It&#39;s The People Versus Parry

Flynt etc. Just as well, really, &#39;cos dodging&#39;s 
only so useful when you&#39;re a tiny fluffy kitten in

pyjamas and the boss you&#39;re fighting is swinging 
a poleax the size of a very inefficiently designed

lamppost. And the hand-drawn animation is all 
very nice but apparently they couldn&#39;t always

be arsed to draw turning around animations, so 
every now and again you&#39;ll dodge through a guy to

avoid his hit and he&#39;ll just instantly flip left 
to right like a sufficiently bribed politician

with a weathervane up his arse. So yeah, on the 
whole best to stick with Parry and the Hendersons.

Not only does it reliably cancel damage 
it also refills your talisman power,

a fairly unique mechanic in which Yi runs past 
a dude, slaps a post-it note onto them reading

&quot;IOU one ass kicking&quot; and then a second later 
their heart explodes from the anticipation,

I guess. It&#39;s initially awkward to use &#39;cos 
you need to keep the button held down until

the payoff, so instead of walking away 
from the explosion with your back turned

like a cool guy you have to awkwardly hang 
around the crime scene for a bit asking if

anyone knows where the bathroom is. But then 
about halfway through the game I unlocked an

ability that would make the talismans 
explode automatically and with that,

the combat clicked. Cool guy explosion walkaway 
was back on. That&#39;s when it started feeling like

anime combat. Where the hero sweeps past the 
bad guy, and it looks like he missed and the

bad guy&#39;s standing there looking confused but 
then, oop, bad guy&#39;s head falls off while the

hero&#39;s across the room feigning interest 
in a vending machine or whatever. So on

the whole the core combat works pretty well 
for me, the occasionally low frame rate of

the animation fucks with the parry timing a bit 
but nothing you can&#39;t learn to compensate for.

Honestly, what kept it fun was much the same as 
what kept Another Crab&#39;s Treasure fun - that it

wasn&#39;t as crushingly hard as so many soulslikes 
feel they need to be these days. As I say,

it did take time for the combat 
to fully click, but when it did,

some of the fucking standard enemies were 
more of a challenge than some of the boss

fights. &#39;Cos they&#39;d jump out of the bushes going 
&quot;Parry time! Think fast!&quot; And I&#39;d be like &quot;Fellas,

I&#39;m just trying to get to the bus stop.&quot; Having 
said that, there was a point towards the end where

the boss fights did start extracting more than 
the regulation amount of piss. Starting with the

big teddy bear lady in the fucked up dreamworld 
setting that made me go &quot;Oh I&#39;ve just remembered

these guys used to make surreal horror games.&quot; 
&#39;Cos this was where the bosses started pulling

out the surprise second and third phases, one of 
my personal pet hates in soulslikes. I mean what&#39;s

the fucking point of a health bar if emptying it 
doesn&#39;t mean you&#39;re finished? It&#39;s like finally

paying off your student loans and then the bank 
says &quot;Oh sorry there&#39;s another set of student

loans we didn&#39;t tell you about. And these ones 
are bigger and you have to pay them off with your

head stuck in a box of crabs. You really killed 
my good mood, asshole! I had a holiday booked!

Alright, I&#39;ve had my moan. There&#39;s no 
denying that Nine Sols kept pulling me back,

for all its late game difficulty spikes and 
slightly awkward interface. The combat and

exploration were stimulating enough, but I 
think the story was the main draw. I liked

piecing together the fucked up background of this 
strange opulence that surrounded me, the hideous

machinations of the boss characters masking 
their deeply flawed humanity. And I liked Yi,

mostly I liked playing a game along these 
lines where the main character is NOT a

clueless musclehead or literal corpse being wound 
up and sent on a rampage at the behest of powers

beyond their understanding. I liked that Yi had 
his own agenda we weren&#39;t sure of. Opinions on

things. I liked that he had a nice apartment 
set up in a cozy little corner of the map, to

underline that he has an investment in the future 
and isn&#39;t just Kratosing his way through powerful

figures merely for revenge or nihilism. And that 
he lets a lost child live in his apartment who

ends up becoming his main connection to humanity 
amid the horror and violence. Although we don&#39;t

know if he does this purely out of altruism or 
if there might be some less wholesome reason

why a powerful figure with clearly very 
suppressed emotions should want to keep

a beautiful hairless boy in their private rooms. 
I&#39;m pretty sure it wasn&#39;t to swap Yu-Gi-Oh cards.
